I'm largely feeling that this game just isn't for me. I've played DS1-3, Bloodborne and Elden Ring, so I'm not a stranger to difficult games, but I'm just not having fun with this one. 

It's very boss oriented and it's quite clear the devs didn't care about the stuff between the bosses as much as the bosses themselves. Trash mobs that require little to no strategy or pattern learning to beat and very little variety in a given area. The environmental design is nice to look at (although water effects leave something to be desired), so it's a bit of a shame that there's not more of it between bosses to wind down and experiment safely with the new things you got from the last boss. In one area, there's new enemies which quite easily and quickly poison you, which the game will tell you that you can heal using a specific item that you can buy at a vendor. The caveat being that the one shop you buy them at has limited stock and doesn't refresh until set points in the game, so if you buy and use them all, you're shit out of luck. You can try grinding for them from enemy drops but they're not guaranteed. 

The graphics are beautiful if you have hardware that can handle it too, but it's a taxing game. Framerates could be better and this game is yet another one that requires heavy use of upscaling, something which soured the visuals a bit in my experience, where I noticed noise mostly in reflections which was quite jarring to me. For reference, I'm using what the game recommended, which at 4k with a 5080 was DLSS balanced. One thing the game could've benefitted from was HDR. A modern AAA game pushing graphics should really have it, especially one which uses a quite wide range of colours and brightness levels.

The bosses are a challenge, some more or less than others (especially depending on the order you do them, looking at you Wondering Wight), but I'm not getting the same feeling that I have in the past with the soulsborne games when I finally figure out a boss. There's no elated feeling of success, just relief that it's over, only to remember that there's going to be another boss within the next 10 minutes (frequently less than that) which quickly turns relief into dread. This isn't helped by bosses feeling like a slog, at least partially due to inputs feeling delayed at times and outright ignored at others. Dodges frequently not happening, lack of cancelling in some scenarios, heals just not happening when windows for them are often just large enough to fit one in, uncharged heavy attacks taking a second before they actually start which gives the impression that they might've been ignored or cancelled until it's too late. This game clearly wants you to play in a methodical, less spammy way, but in this implementation, it's to the detrement of feeling like I'm in control all the time.
